0.text: G'Day Viewers, My Name is Graeme Stevenson

3.text:
and I 'd like to invite you to come on
a journey of creativity and learning,

6.text:
and adventure through this series,
Colour In Your Life.

9.text:
There's an artist in every family
throughout the world,

12.text:
and lots of times there's an artist
deep down inside all of us as well,

15.text:
so grab your kids, your
brothers, your sisters,

19.text:
your Auntie’s, Uncles'
and Mum's and Dad's,

21.text:
and come and see how some the best
artists in Australia do what they do.

63.text:
(Graeme) Well g'day viewers and
welcome back to Colour In Your Life.

65.text:
(Graeme) We're actually up in Brisbane
today at Wynnum just on the coast,
it's just beautiful outside today.

71.text:
(Graeme) And we are with a very, very
talented lady. We're going to spend
the day with her, De Gillett.

76.text:
(Graeme) Welcome to the
show. Thank you so much.
(De) Hello Graeme.

78.text:
(Graeme) Now De's a teacher, a fabulous teacher,
a number of students, does life drawing.

84.text:
(Graeme) We're actually in the
studio workshop area at the moment.

86.text:
(Graeme) But De's also, I really could say
you're an academic as far as art is concerned.

91.text:
(Graeme) But in saying that, you've got a degree
in fine art from the Queensland College of Arts.

97.text:
(De) But you know I got to fifty-two
and thought I wanted this since
I was sixteen, so hurry up, really.

103.text: (De) So yes, I graduated last December.

105.text:
(Graeme) I think it's so important that De,
I mean fifty-two years of age and you sort of
say ‘I'm going to go and do a fine art's degree’.

111.text:
(Graeme) That's fabulous, I think that's
just wonderful. But I think also, in looking
at De's CV and speaking to her, is that you also,

120.text:
(Graeme) disregardless of the academic side
of things, there is a real purist essence about
who you are as an artist and as a teacher.

127.text:
(Graeme) Can you tell me little bit more,
I mean you go into, particularly when
it comes to cubists and Picasso.

131.text:
(Graeme) There's a certain psychology that you
still look towards when you do what you do.

134.text:
(De) Absolutely. What really interests me is
joy and abundance. And using art to
bring more of that into the world.

142.text:
(De) Now when I was at uni they tried to
explain to me that my ideas were the only
important thing and how well I painted or drew

149.text:
(De) was completely immaterial. But
that's what I have to bring in the world.

153.text:
(De) I don't pin my guts to the wall and be the
person who is joyous and full of life and abundance

158.text:
(De) then that art isn't going to exist.
And I want it to exist because it makes
the world a better place. I'm on a mission.

164.text: (Graeme) Absolutely you are. When you see De's art you'll understand because it is so electric. It's so tactile as well,

171.text: (Graeme) I mean she really paints in layers and layers of impasto and colour. It's just one of those forms of art that when you look at it,

178.text: (Graeme) and I was doing it before when I walked into the studio, I’m going, ‘I can't keep me hands off this stuff’.

181.text: (De) I nearly had to slap him honestly.

183.text:
(Graeme) But it is going to be a great day.
Apart from the litany of awards you've had,
you've got this huge track record.

191.text:
(Graeme) I mean, I was actually downloading
De's information when I first spoke to her,

194.text:
(Graeme) the pages just kept printing
out and I said ‘this is nuts’.

197.text:
(Graeme) But I read through it and I thought
‘well we can't get through it all’.

200.text:
(Graeme) But obviously when you go and
have a look at De's website yourself,

203.text:
(Graeme) you'll be able to see the amazing
CV that she's got. It's just extraordinary.

207.text:
(Graeme) But today we're going to be doing
a picture of one of your loves and obviously
there's a lot of nature in your work as well.

212.text:
(Graeme) We are going to be doing
a painting of Rainbow Lorikeets.

217.text:
(De) I'm really interested in the notion, the
cubist notion of simultaneity. So where things
are, where they were, and where they will be.

224.text:
(De) And birds in flight just give me all
that, all of that abundance and joy and
movement, and they're just pretty too.

232.text: (De) So yeah, that's a good thing.

233.text:
(Graeme) Alright well I'm going to take my
normal seat just on the side here and
I'm going to let you do what you do.

263.text:
(Graeme) Okay De, well I can see that you've mixed
up a whole bunch of Atelier Interactives there.

268.text:
(Graeme) And did you put some impasto or
some moulding gel in that? What was it?

273.text:
(De) No this was just gesso.
I like the Chromacryl Gesso.
(Graeme) So you've just put the gesso in have you?

277.text:
(De) Yeah because it's important at this
stage that the colours are mid toned.

281.text:
(Graeme) I want them light to mid tone
because it's really easy to get too dark.

286.text:
(De) I'm trying to develop interest and
excitement in this early layer of the painting.

290.text:
(Graeme) And you're using
a fan brush there.

292.text:
(De) Yes, my favorite gnarly,
horrible, rotten fan brushes.

296.text: (Graeme) You’re a big fan of fan brushes?

298.text: (De) A huge fan of fan brushes.

300.text:
(De) I see what you did there. I'm a huge
fan of fan brushes because when I started
as an artist I was poverty struck and

307.text:
(De) I could get fan brushes really, really cheap. And
I hate to tell you that was my big, big motivation.

313.text:
(Graeme) But in saying that you still
use really high quality paint as well.

317.text:
(De) Absolutely. Because if you're going to sell
paintings to the public they have to last. If it's
all going to fall off your canvas in six months,

326.text:
(De) I don't think so.
That's not a nice thing.

328.text:
(Graeme) I even notice with your
canvas you're on linen as well.

333.text:
(Graeme) Yeah I mean it’s generosity towards
the painting as well to be able to do that.

336.text:
(Graeme) How did you develop this
style that you're doing now?

340.text:
(Graeme) I mean your work is so different
to anything else I've seen once again.

344.text:
(De) Yeah, basically I wasn't taught to paint.
I was a drawer so I worked in pastels a lot.
I was really terrified of paint.

353.text:
(De) I'm sure viewers can relate to that.
I got hold of a lot of second hand art equipment
and included a whole lot of paints.

360.text:
(De) And a very dear friend of mine, who’s
an art teacher, spent about six weeks
with me in my studio.

366.text:
(De) And we played with paint for six weeks.
Part of it was some clear gel medium
that I use a lot in my work.

371.text:
(Graeme) You can always read people
personality in their work as well. You've
got a very exuberant personality,

378.text:
(Graeme) you're a well known teacher as
well. I think that's really part of being a great
teacher also, is to have someone that's really

384.text:
(Graeme) exuberant about their work and about
their life and that's exactly who you are.

387.text:
(De) Well if I'm not excited about it, how can
I expect everyone else to be excited about it?

393.text:
(De) And it is exciting.
Making art is so exciting.

395.text:
(Graeme) Very true. Alright the excitement
continues. What are we going to do now?

401.text:
(De) So spatter is a way of just
getting some liveliness into things.
(Graeme) Yeah.

407.text:
(De) So what I'm going to use is my Atelier
paints. Got to love this brand of paints.

412.text:
(Graeme) But the colours
are brilliant aren’t they?

415.text:
(Graeme) So thick and luxurious.
Or as you would say, sumptuous.

419.text:
(De) Sumptuous. Sumptuous, juicy, reckless
are favorite words of mine.
Okay so the fine art of spatter.

427.text:
(Graeme) Oh what do I do?
We can have a paint fight.

431.text:
(De) Yeah. What I want you to do is, we're going
to develop some areas of splatter, so one here.

441.text:
(De) And one up there. So what I want
you to do is load up your brush.
(Graeme) Yeah.

445.text:
(De) And then just, when your brush
stops, the paint’s going to come off it.

450.text:
(Graeme) So I just do that over the top of yours?
(De) Yeah.
(Graeme) Okay.

452.text:
(De) I'll be the locator with my Quinacridone
Magenta here and you just follow me along.

457.text:
(De) So one of the important things about spatter is you can
use it to give a sense of perspective right from the start.

465.text:
(De) So when your brush is fully loaded Graeme…
(Graeme) Yes.

468.text:
(De) You'll get big dots and as it
empties out you'll get smaller ones.

472.text:
(De) So if you concentrate your bigger dots
down here at the front under the painting,

476.text:
(De) it'll straight away get that whole
spacial thing happening where
the top part of the painting is

481.text: (De) further away from us than the bottom.

483.text:
(Graeme) How about that?
(De)  It's good fun huh.

486.text:
(Graeme) Ah it’s just the great enjoyment.
(De) Alright that's enough.

489.text:
(Graeme) Yeah, yeah I feel
like I'm getting carried away.

491.text:
(De) Put the brushes down and
move away from the painting.

494.text:
(De) And now because I know there's going
to be some wings in here, what I'm
going to do is comb some of this.

500.text:
(De) So I'm going to
pull this with my comb…

502.text:
(Graeme) Ah.
(De) …just lightly. That needs to dry.

505.text:
(Graeme) Okay we'll let that dry and
then we move onto the next section.

524.text:
(Graeme) Well as you can see De has actually
moved on, the canvas has dried, but there's a
beautiful, beautiful soft pattern in here as well.

531.text:
(Graeme) And you're actually using charcoal to sketch
out your main characters, which are obviously,

537.text:
(Graeme) you've actually got cockatoos that
you're turning into lorikeets, is that right?

544.text:
(De) Exactly. I'm just giving myself a
fairly rough guideline. Okay, I'm finished
drawing for the moment.

551.text:
(De) We're going to move on to
the next most exciting thing.
(Graeme) Great.

554.text:
(De) I'm going to be mixing the
Chromachryl texture paste. I really like
the consistency of this particular brand.

560.text:
(De) I find some of the modeling compounds
are too stiff and when I try and push them
through the plastic bag,

566.text:
(De) I explode the plastic
bag all over the place.

568.text:
(Graeme) Oh fair enough. And you just use
sandwich bags do you, in doing that?

572.text:
(De) Well that's the next process. Right now…
(Graeme) Okay.

574.text: (De) I'm going to be using palette knives.

576.text:
(Graeme) Okay. And you do, with your particular
techniques, you do use a lot of paint don't you?

581.text:
(Graeme) These are three dimensional paintings,
that's the best way I can describe them.

587.text:
(De) So what I'm doing here is a loaded
blend of paint and textured paste.

593.text:
(De) I want this to stay sitting up as it dries.
Okay so I've mixed that…
(Graeme) Yeah.

598.text:
(De) …not very well. It's a bit like muffin mix,
you don't want to, you don't want kill it.
(Graeme) Okay.

602.text:
(De) So I've got my biggest palette knife,
loaded up, making sure that the paint is still
variegated and it’s all the way to the end.

612.text:
(De) And then what I'm going
to do is bed it down here.
(Graeme) Yeah.

616.text:
(De) So give it a little squish…
(Graeme) Yeah.

619.text:
(De) …so that it builds up either side of the
blade and then I'm going to create a feather.

625.text: (Graeme) Look at that. Isn't that great?

628.text:
(Graeme) And when you say variegated
it really means you've got a lot of the
colours in there that are separated.

633.text:
(De) Yes, correct.
(Graeme) Sumptuous is the word.
(De) Recklessly sumptuous.

637.text:
(Graeme) Recklessly sumptuous, that's
wonderful. You do travel around a lot
doing workshops don't you?

643.text:
(De) I do. And there's this thing that happens
where, when I go one time, they have me back.

649.text:
(De) So I've been, I've done
four workshops in Tassy now.

652.text:
(De) And I’ve done, I've been to Dubbo
a lot of times. I'm going there to judge
their annual art competition…

660.text:
(Graeme) I can see why. You've only got
to spend a little bit of time with De to find out
that her personality is quite electric

667.text:
(Graeme) but it's just really fun to be with
her. And fun to see what she does, it really is.

673.text: (De) You say the nicest things, Graeme.

675.text: (Graeme) But it's the truth, it really is.

678.text:
(De) Okay so now I'll start again on the other
side to pull it in. But because, because I can't,
I'm left handed, I have to work left handed,

687.text:
(De) so I'll have to turn it all around. I
think working with the natural flow of
your body is really important.

696.text:
(De) It's also really important to work with the
big muscles of your elbow and your shoulder rather
than the little tiny stuff of your fingers.

703.text:
(De) I think with dynamic work like this. You
know let your body speak, make it a mind,
body visceral whole story.

712.text:
(Graeme) You're obviously Mediterranean
from somewhere aren’t you?

714.text:
(De) I lived in Ingham for a long time.
(Graeme) Did you? Okay.
(De) A lot of Italian folks there.

719.text: (Graeme) Untie my hands, I need to speak.

721.text:
(De) Precisely. One of the hardest things about being
an artist is getting out of your own way and just

730.text:
(De) understanding that the
universe knows better than you do.

733.text:
(De) And if you can get out of your own way
and your own ego and let that happen you're
going to have some better work.

740.text:
(De) The possibilities are much more open. Okay,
so I'm going to go now with the second row of
feathers along the inside of the wing.

750.text:
(De) So I'm just drawing here on my knowledge
of where the feathers sit in a bird’s wing.

755.text:
(Graeme) It's like sculpture with paint. It's unreal.
(De) Well I was a sculptor…

761.text:
(Graeme) Oh okay.
(De) …for twelve years. I've sculptured my
way through eight tons of clay.

765.text:
(Graeme) Oh goodness.
(De) Art chooses us, we don't choose it.
You know, deny that at your own peril.

772.text:
(De) You are going to be a miserable person
if you don't paint. Do it. Get inspired.
(Graeme) She's brilliant.

778.text:
(De) You could watch Put Some Colour In Your
Life and get a whole lot of new
techniques. How does that work?

783.text:
(Graeme) Oh it's wonderful. Okay so you're
going to turn it around and you're
going to show us a technique

790.text:
(Graeme) and then we're going to move
on and let you work for a little while.
(De) Yep.

794.text:
(Graeme) A technique involving
the body and some doilies?

799.text:
(De) Highly technical
piece of equipment again.

801.text:
(Graeme) That's great.
(De) Get these from your local art shop.
(Graeme) Yeah.

804.text:
(De) Don't tell the ladies what you're doing with
them because you know what's going to happen is

808.text:
(De) they'll refuse to sell them to you. If you
say I'm going to cut these up and push paint
through them. No they're not happy about that.

815.text:
(Graeme) You can't do that. But it's a
fascinating technique that just gives
you an amazing texture in your work.

821.text: (Graeme) I love the colours but; they're just so rich.

824.text:
(De) These colours, this brand: marvelous. So what
I'm going to do is locate part of the pattern.

832.text:
(Graeme) Yeah.
(De) That works with the idea of the chest feathers…
(Graeme) Yeah.

838.text:
(De) …and then I'm going to pick up
some yellow and push it through. I can just
see my charcoal drawing through there.

847.text:
(Graeme) I suppose once you get a little bit of paint
on there it tends to stay there anyway does it?

859.text:
(Graeme) There you go. Got to do something
else. But then again that's what
right brain people are like.

862.text:
(Graeme) So how did you come up with this
particular technique? It’s just a matter
of the journey of discovery.
(Graeme) There you go. Got to do something
else. But then again that's what
right brain people are like.

868.text:
(Graeme) There's no way of getting away from it. We
don't, it's very difficult for a right-brained
person to use the word bored at any stage.

876.text:
(De) Definitely.
(Graeme) There's always something you can do.

878.text:
(De) Oh and if you can do things that no
one else has done, then there's the
thrill of discovery as well in that.

886.text: (De) See how I have a harsh line there between the two colours, so I'll just pull down into that.

893.text:
(De) And so then. Can you help
me lift up this one please?

899.text:
(De) Just grab it here and here.
(Graeme) Here and here.

901.text:
(De) And we lift straight up. Ta Da.
(Graeme) Look at that.
(De) Thank you.

906.text:
(Graeme) That's so cool isn't it? No wonder
how you've got such a great three dimensional
effects on it all and it obviously stands out now.

922.text:
(Graeme) because there's obviously some
drying times and everything else involved.

924.text:
(Graeme) And we'll come back in a
little while and keep going with it.

928.text:
(De) Sounds like a plan. Let's do that.
(Graeme) Excellent. See you soon.

979.text:
(De) So I need to mix the colours that I want
and I'll mix the turquoise on a
base of white ink so that it's light.

988.text:
(De) One of the big issues with ink painting
is that it gets, it goes dark very, very easily.
So a little bit of turquoise in there.

999.text:
(Graeme) Yeah. Oh look at that.
(De) Near the kind of colour I'm looking for.
(Graeme) Yeah.

1002.text:
(De) So now I want you to do this one.
(Graeme) Yeah. We're getting surgical now.

1009.text:
(De) If you are someone who likes control,
honestly walk away now. Do not attempt
this technique, it is probably going to kill you.

1017.text:
(De) That's marvelous, Graeme, that's just the
right amount. So now I'm going to drop in some yellow,

1022.text:
(De) so now this is just water in my spray
bottle. So anywhere I can see now that's dry
because it won't be reflective. Just go in.

1050.text:
(De) I want to depress the canvas
because I'm quite interested in
this flow that's developing and

1055.text:
(De) I'd like to encourage it to
continue out into the feathers.

1059.text:
(De) And that's probably as much
ink as it needs I would think.

1063.text:
(De) The hardest thing in making
ink work is to move away from the
painting and let it sit for ten minutes.

1069.text:
(De) And you know in my classes I say
‘leave it for ten minutes’ and then
they come back in two minutes.

1074.text:
(De) It's not ten minutes yet, ten, this many, ten
minutes. Then you can come back in while it's
still really wet you can throw some more ink in.

1083.text:
(De) As soon as it gets thick and honey-like and
starts to dry, don't touch it because you'll ruin it.

1088.text:
(Graeme) Okay. Alright well we'll
let this one dry then.
(De) Okay let's.

1104.text:
(Graeme) Well as you can see, we've taken the
painting from flat and its dried and obviously
as De said the colours will change and

1112.text:
(Graeme) they'll sort of dry in their own
direction. It's got a beautiful finish to it.

1114.text:
(Graeme) Like a silk finish, it's just wonderful.
So what are we going to do now De?
You’re obviously going to finish it off.

1120.text: (Graeme) Where do we go from here?

1121.text:
(De) Well now, because the inks have done
their own thing and they haven't necessarily
gone where I wanted them to,

1127.text:
(De) which is just part of the course. One of
the things you can't do with ink is panic about
that while the flow is happening and

1133.text:
(De) try and correct it because you
just end up with a sea of mud.
(Graeme) Sure.

1136.text:
(De) So you get what you get and then you
work with it. So what I do next is work with
this Impasto Gel Medium.

1143.text:
(De) It's a product that dries clear and shiny.
So the shiny mimics the enamel quality of the
ink, the shininess of that.

1151.text:
(De) But I can make it the colour that I need to,
so that I can repair things like the rhythm.

1158.text:
(De) So here for instance where I've
got this sweep going through here.
(Graeme) Yeah.

1161.text:
(De) It's orange here but the blue ink has overtaken it.
(Graeme) Yeah.

1165.text:
(De) So I'll want to mix
myself up some orange impasto.

1169.text:
(De) So I'll do another one of those loaded
blends where it's yellow on one end
and comes through.

1174.text:
(De) You can feel the difference when
you mix it too. Textured paste feels grainy
when you mix it but this is just smooth.

1182.text:
(De) So I'll work across the ridges and
draw through so that continues there.

1189.text:
(Graeme) When you were saying about
that line breaking the pattern, can you
explain to me what you mean by that?

1195.text:
(De) Well all good paintings should have rhythm.
I always think this bit is like dancing with it.

1201.text:
(De) That you're trying to get it to
this place where it just feels that,

1206.text:
(De) where these lines come out of the
canvas, that they could come around in a great
big swoop and come back in at the top.

1213.text:
(De) So having that rhythm that feels
comfortable, that there's no sort of jagged

1219.text:
(De) interruptions to things
except where you want them.

1222.text:
(De) So it's like a dance for me. That this is
my absolute favorite part of making
a painting because I get to,

1229.text:
(De) I get to sway with it and dance with it. And
just feel, feel my way into it, what it wants to be.

1236.text:
(Graeme) That's great. I can see
it just sort of snaps it out.
(De) It just pops it doesn’t it?

1240.text:
(Graeme) People can learn this from you at your
workshops. Now your actual company name for that is artstree.com.au?

1251.text:
(Graeme) And this is once again a
really, really amazing teacher that
has incredible techniques to learn.

1257.text:
(Graeme) They are all so different but
once again De's one of those people and

1260.text:
(Graeme) you can just tell by the way she
talks, is obviously a brilliant teacher.

1263.text:
(Graeme) So I would suggest anyone that's
in the Brisbane area if they want to get together
with a really, really great master teacher,

1270.text:
(Graeme) who has been through the whole
gamut as far as the academic side is concerned
and the practical side is concerned.

1275.text:
(Graeme)  She understands how artists feel
about what they create. But come along to
this lady, I think you'll have an amazing,

1282.text:
(Graeme) I mean we've had a great
day, which has been fabulous but…

1284.text:
(De) Thank you Graeme. The Inks
Workshops are my most popular thing.

1288.text:
(De) And people come along and say things
like "Well, I thought it was going to be fun,

1292.text:
(De) but I didn't know it was
going to be this much fun!"

1294.text:
(Graeme) Well that was about as interesting a
day as you could possibly have painting with
a really great teacher. De, thank you so much.

1304.text:
(Graeme) It was absolutely wonderful. Now if
you'd like to see more of what De does and
enquire about her workshops and her DVD's,

1310.text:
(Graeme) she's got a collection of great DVD's
coming out so you should go and have a look
at those. You can go to artstree.com.au?

1318.text:
(De) Correct.
(Graeme) Excellent. Go in there have a
look at their website. It's just full.

1321.text:
(Graeme) You can get all the workshop
details, it's just full of information. See De's
work, see all the other guys work as well.

1326.text:
(Graeme) See what they create because it really
turns out to be just a fabulous day
with this woman. It's amazing.

1332.text:
(Graeme) Thank you so much for being on the show.
We'd also like to thank our sponsors as usual.

1337.text:
(Graeme) Chroma as usual is always behind us
and as you can see De was using Chroma
products today. They really are fabulous.

1342.text:
(Graeme) We have a number of sponsors
coming on board these days, we'd
really like to thank them as well.

1346.text:
(Graeme) They're also in our website. But we'll
leave it from there. We are going to
head out and go south after this one.

1353.text: (Graeme) But as we always say, remember…

1356.text: (De) To put some Colour In Your Life.

1359.text:
(Graeme) Thanks guys. See you again.
(De) Bye.
(Graeme) Bye.
